[snip...]

> >3) Increased connectivity pulls points closer together and speeds evolution.
> >
> >4) Increased connectivity increases the size of "neighborhood" around each
> >point, and slows evolution.
> >
> >5) So there's a trade-off between 3 and 4, which is problem dependent and
> >nobody knows how to estimate the best compromise.
> >
> >
>Putting my phased search hat on for a moment. Perhaps switching between
>different types of mutation could be beneficial, the search could spend
>time finding a local optimum in the current landscape, and then we
>change the landscape to search for wdier solutions, if we find one then
>switch back to searching for local solutions. This is a generalisation
>of course, you could have many different fitness landscape schemes to
>choose from. So just periodically cycling through different schemes
>might be better than any one scheme on it's own. One very rudamentary
>implementation of this idea would be to periodically take a champion
>genome from NEAT and to just perform weight mutation (no topology
>mutations), in order to find the optimal weights fro the current best
>toplogy.

I think that's a really good insight.  However, there's a downside as well.

One of the things about higher-dimensional spaces is that our intuition 
about them is really poor.

In this case, how much "volume" grows with increasing radius is very much 
disproportionate to the 3D spaces we are used too (in fact, most people 
visualize in 2D and even underestimate 3D volumes).

Thus, in a 3D space:

radius * 2 implies volume * 8

in a 100D space:

radius * 2 implies volume * 1267650600228229401496703205376

Which brings me to the down-side of long-ranged mutations.  E.g. suppose in 
one phase we use mutations equivalent to "short" steps across the space, in 
the phase and there could be (say) 1 billion "local" genomes accessible 
(again, say) 10 are fitter than us.  Suppose that then we "stall" and 
switch to another phase using mutations equivalent to "long" steps across 
the space, now there are (yet again say) 1E50 genomes accessible and (yet 
another figure off the top of my head) 100 are better then the current one.

[[I base "100" on the idea that (i) an interesting problem might have 100 
different "strategies" meaning 100 different remote "meta optima", and (ii) 
very optimistically, I'm supposing we can hit each of those meta optima at 
least once with the "long steps", and (iii) also very optimistically, I'm 
supposing that when we do hit a meta optimum, we hit it far enough up the 
slope that it looks better than the current solution]]

So basically what I'm saying is that once a population gets "locked in" on 
a particular "strategy".  Any steps long enough to walk it out of the local 
meta-optimum, unless the meta optimum is really low, has no chance of 
hitting a genome which will out perform the current population champion.

Of course, this is where species come in, because a new species arising 
from a "long step" can compete amongst itself until it out-performs the 
previous best species.  However we must consider the vastness of the space 
again, that species might take along while to get out of the doldrums, and 
may itself "stall" several times on the way to it's sun-lit uplands...

On this basis, do people agree that strategies which leave species alone 
for absolutely as long as possible might be the way to go?

What about the idea that speciation should be a matter of degree.  e.g. you 
reach it's own really good peaks, a "species" might itself need jolting out 
of lesser optima a few times, so the species taken in isolation might need 
to enter a different "phase", but not such a drastic phase as to be made 
immediately extinct in competition with the population winner...

i.e. we may have species:

1.1
1.2
2.1
2.2
2.3

etc and:

1) individuals in 2.1 compete only with one another -- in every generation
2) 2.1 enters a "broad phase" only when it stalls
3) sub-species 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3 compete with one another, but only on a 
long time scale
4) the whole of species 2 can enter a "very broad phase" only when all its 
sub-species are stalled
5) species 1 and 2 compete with one another, but only on the longest time scale
6) the whole population can enter a "broadest phase" only when the whole 
thing is stalled

If I were really implementing this, I would not stop at just two levels of 
speciation.  I also would not use anything as rigid as an a.b.c type 
system.  I would probably just track the descent of individuals from common 
ancestors.  Thus a set of brothers would form the smallest 
"sub-sub-sub-...-sub-species" and the whole thing would proceed 
hierarchically through cousins, uncles... up to some threshold where I 
would call them "unrelated".

Thoughts anybody...
